data.title: Sid James and Laurence Harvey
data.text:
Saul W. Issroff

1976 Sidney James, actor (Lavander Hill Mob, Carry On), dies at 65.Sid James

(May 8, 1913 - June 26, 1976) b. Newcastle, Natal, South Africa, ) was a

film and television actor.

Sid James (born Sidney Joel Cohen) grew up in Doornfontein , Johannesburg

in a very eastern European Lithuanian origin Jewish community. He managed a

very good Cockney accent as an actor in later years. see

http://www.carryonline.com/carry/sid.html

Sid James was a South African-born Jew whose parents worked in the music

hall business. James had joined a South African regiment of the British Army

in 1939 and soon became a producer in its entertainment unit. As such he was

typical of a generation of British performers and writers who learned their

trade while in the Armed Forces. After the service, James arrived in London

on Christmas Day 1946 looking to make a start in acting. His grizzled face

meant that he became typecast as minor gangsters in his early film

appearances. His career success came when he transformed himself into a

quintessential Londoner, an ordinary bloke, who drew sympathy >from his

audience despite playing a rascal

in many of his roles.

He is buried in Golders Green Crematorium, where other humourists of Jewish

origin, who died of coronary thromboses, e.g. Peter Sellers, also have

their ashes scattered as fertiliser!

Another Jewish origin actor, Laurence Harvey was born October 1, 1928 in

Joniskis, Lithuania. His real name was Laruschka Mischa Skikne, which he

changed when his parents emigrated to South Africa to escape persecution for

their Jewish faith. At 15, he debuted on stage with the Johannesburg

Repertory Theater, but later he joined the army and served until the end of

WWII. He went to England after the war and enrolled at the Royal Academy of

Dramatic Art, staying there three months before joining a Manchester

repertory company where he soon began to play leads. He was married three

times first to Margaret Leighton in 1957, then to Joan Cohn in 1968 and then

to Pauline Stone in 1972. They had one daughter named Domino. After his

breakthrough film Room at the Top in 1959, he worked steadily until his

death >from stomach cancer at his home in Hampstead, London, in 1973.

http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=6304843&pt=Laurence%20Harvey

There seems to be a discrepancy as he appears to be buried in Santa

Barabara!
